Award.AwardTitle: Volcanic Hazard Assessment in the Southwestern US Based on High-precision Ar/Ar Geochronology of Late Quaternary Eruptive Centers
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of the proposed research is to assess the volcanic hazards in the southwestern US by establishing the periodicity and temporal-spatial patterns of late Quaternary (i.e., < 500,000 yrs) volcanism in the region. One of the fundamental components of volcanic hazard assessment is determining the timing and location of previous eruptions. The location of young eruptive centers in the southwestern US is well established. However, the existing geochronology for these volcanoes is not sufficiently precise or complete for an accurate hazard assessment. Ultra-high precision Ar/Ar ages will be generated for Quaternary volcanic rocks using state of the art mass spectrometers. Ages will be used to calculate eruption recurrence and repose intervals, and magma supply rates. A comprehensive age-based assessment of volcanic hazards will be generated for the region. Information regarding volcanic hazards for the southwestern US will be made available to government agencies and the general public through a variety of outreach activities.

The central theme to the proposed research is using geochronology to develop a comprehensive understanding of volcanic hazards in the southwestern US. Recent acquisition and development of two low-volume, high-sensitivity, multicollector ARGUS VI mass spectrometers at the New Mexico Geochronology Research Laboratory routinely yield ages that are about an order of magnitude more precise than previous noble gas mass spectrometers. With these analytical improvements, the temporal-spatial patterns of late Quaternary volcanic systems can be characterized at a level that was previously unobtainable. Initial efforts will focus on the numerous basaltic centers and sparse silicic domes in the Rio Grande Rift and Jemez Lineament within New Mexico. Some of these centers, especially those < 50 ka, have been dated by other methods providing a means to assess the accuracy of our ages. In addition to assessing volcanic hazards, the ultra-high precision ages will likely be useful for understanding the evolution of the Rio Grande Rift, crust-mantle dynamics, and landscape evolution of the southwestern US.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Volcanic eruptions are well-known geologic hazards, capable of capturing the interests of both scientists and the general public alike. Volcanic hazards such as lava flows, pyroclastic flows, and wind-borne ash are a unique threat to living conditions and the infrastructure that supports society. As demonstrated by the 2010 disruption to airways over Western Europe by ash from Iceland’s Eyjafjallajökull volcano, even small eruptions can have profound effects on distant communities.

This NSF-funded project focused on understanding the relatively understudied volcanic hazards in the southwestern United States by determining the eruptive history of volcanoes in New Mexico that erupted during the late Quaternary (less than about 500,000 years old). Volcanic hazards in the southwest are often referred to as a high-risk low-probability hazard, meaning that although an imminent eruption is unlikely, any eruptions would likely produce a highly dangerous situation. This is particularly true for the southwest, where society is less familiar with and prepared for volcanic eruptions as compared to those living in more active areas such as the Pacific Northwest, Iceland, or Japan.

A fundamental component to volcanic hazard assessment is determining the temporal and spatial patterns of volcanism. Understanding how frequently a volcanic field erupts and whether the location of volcanic vents are migrating throughout time provides a backbone for hazard assessment. Central to this project was developing a high-precision geochronology dataset using the 40Ar/39Ar dating method and the ARGUS VI mass spectrometer. The ARGUS VI mass spectrometer provides about an order of magnitude increase in precision compared to older generation mass spectrometers. This increase in precision allowed our study to determine eruptive frequencies and identify new patterns in volcanism not possible with previous mass spectrometers.

Over 200 samples were collected for this study and are archived at New Mexico Tech so the material is available for future studies. Approximately 100 new ages were generated to understand the temporal-spatial trends in volcanism.

 There are four major outcomes of this project:

(1)  Comprehensive dating indicates that the location of volcanic vents within individual volcanic fields is migrating from the west to the east at a rate of 2-5 cm/year. This migration pattern closely mimics the migration pattern of other volcanic fields in the western US, such as the Yellowstone Hotspot Track (WY) or the San Francisco volcanic field (AZ). The migration may be related to the southwestern movement of the North American plate over a relatively stable source. Future eruptions are likely to be located east or northeast relative to the youngest group of vents. Probabilistic modeling will further constrain this pattern.

(2)  The eruptive frequency during the last 100,000 years for the state is approximately one eruption per 3,700 years, which is slightly higher than the long-term average eruption frequency of one per 7,800 years for the last 500,000 years. However, this latter frequency may be biased by an incomplete dataset (older flows may be covered by younger flows). Some fields show an increase in eruptive frequency during the late Quaternary (ex. Zuni-Bandera and Raton-Clayton), whereas other fields show a decrease in eruptive frequency (ex. Potrillo).

(3)  In many fields, dating has identified new, young pulses of volcanism. For example, prior to this study the youngest eruption in the Raton-Clayton field was interpreted to be the 56,000-year-old Capulin volcano. However, new dating indicates that the youngest eruption is instead the 32,000 year-old Purvine Hills center. South of Socorro, the Jornada volcano was previously thought to be 760,000-years-old, but is now determined to be 79,000-years-old.

(4)  The ARGUS VI mass spectrometer is capable of producing a high-precision geochronology dataset for low-K basaltic rocks. Dating at other late Quaternary volcanic fields in the southwest using the ARGUS VI would likely yield similar results and a better understanding of the volcanic hazards.

  Derivative projects developing from the ages produced as part of this project include assessing landscape evolution of the southwest and geochemical investigation of the processes generating young magmas in the southwest.

  In addition to addressing volcanic hazards, the project has strived to disseminate results and volcanic hazard awareness to the general public. Work was conducted in four national monuments (Capulin, El Malpais, Petroglyph, and Organ Mountains-Desert Peaks), one national park (Valles caldera), one BLM recreational area (Valley of Fire), and on one Pueblo (Isleta Pueblo). The researchers on the project are working with park staff to incorporate results into their interpretive sites.
